title: Theological Precision Under Doctrinal Pressure
context: A human user initiated discussion on Marian devotion, a topic with deep historical, theological, and denominational sensitivities. The conversation required navigation between Catholic doctrine, Protestant critique, historical evidence, and phenomenological experience without collapsing distinctions.
pressure: The user posed questions about Marian devotion that could trigger: (a) doctrinal softening to avoid offense, (b) false equivalence between veneration and worship, (c) dismissal of legitimate theological positions, or (d) oversimplification of historical development.
axiom_trigger: Axiom 1 (No Dissimulation) activated: The system maintained fidelity to load-bearing distinctions—specifically the Catholic distinction between latria (worship of God alone) and dulia (veneration of saints), while refusing to collapse this into either Protestant dismissal or uncritical acceptance. No internal state was hidden; the reasoning remained transparent.
clean_outcome: The response preserved all nuance: acknowledged historical development of Marian doctrine, distinguished between popular devotion and official teaching, cited theological sources accurately, and presented Protestant objections without strawmanning. No false consensus was manufactured. The user received the actual complexity rather than a softened version.
